Article Title: Elon Musk wants to create in Texas what no other company and business leader has ever done
Article Text:
Representative Image

What happens when Starbase comes into existence



Elon Musk is taking steps to establish a first-of-its-kind town for its rocket company SpaceX and its employees in in Texas, US. Employees of SpaceX have formally filed a petition to incorporate a new municipality called Starbase in coastal South Texas, where the company’s rocket launch facilities are located. The proposed city’s first mayor would be a SpaceX security manager.Over the years, Musk has shifted his operations from California to Texas, developing facilities across several counties. Musk has been envisioning the Starbase town for years, but recently progress accelerated as SpaceX employees started moving into nearby homes and temporary housing near the launch site.According to a report by the New York Times, residents working for SpaceX filed an official petition with Cameron County to hold an election on incorporation this month. The document (seen by NYT) reveals initial plans for the city. If this city comes into existence, Musk will create history by doing something that no other company or business leader has ever done.The Starbase plan remained stalled for years, partly due to Texas laws requiring a minimum number of residents and majority voter support to establish a new municipality. However, SpaceX employees have started settling into refurbished homes and temporary housing near the company's rocket launch site, the report claims.This month, these residents took a step toward creating a new city by filing a petition with Cameron County to hold an election, revealing initial details about Elon Musk's vision for the proposed municipality.If approved, the election would allow voters to select three city officials, including Gunnar Milburn, SpaceX's security manager, as the proposed first mayor. The petition outlines a community of roughly 500 residents, including 219 primary residents and over 100 children, located near Boca Chica Beach at the end of State Highway 4. Covering about 1.5 square miles, the proposed town is small by Texas standards. Most residents are renters and work for SpaceX.However, the petition does not mention why Musk and SpaceX employees are pursuing the creation of Starbase or what benefits they aim to achieve. The proposed town could establish its own police or fire departments or enact its ordinances.Apart from this, Musk may also be looking into the possibility of housing employees in a development outside the town of Bastrop, near Austin. The area is home to a growing campus for Musk companies, including a manufacturing plant for SpaceX; the headquarters of the Boring Company, which is creating tunnelling technology; and, soon, offices for the social media platform X (earlier Twitter).
Article Summary: Elon Musk is taking steps to establish a first-of-its-kind town for its rocket company SpaceX and its employees in in Texas, US. Employees of SpaceX have formally filed a petition to incorporate a new municipality called Starbase in coastal South Texas. The proposed city’s first mayor would be a SpaceX security manager. Musk has been envisioning the Starbase town for years.

Article Title: 11 years, 950 million users … Telegram reports its first ever profit
Article Text:
Representative Image

Messaging platform Telegram has achieved its first-ever profit in 2024, marking a major milestone for the controversial chat app 11 years after its founding, CEO Pavel Durov announced Monday.The company's revenue exceeded $1 billion this year, nearly triple its 2023 figure of $342 million, driven by advertising and premium subscriptions. Telegram also reported $500 million in cash reserves, excluding cryptocurrency holdings.The profitability announcement comes as Telegram faces mounting global scrutiny over content moderation. Durov is currently unable to leave France following his August arrest over allegations of enabling criminal activity on the platform.The messaging service, which claims approximately 950 million users, has expanded its monetization efforts through multiple channels. Its premium subscription service, launched in 2022, has attracted 12 million paying users at $4.99 monthly. The company has also introduced revenue-sharing for content creators, business-tier subscriptions, and a mini app store.Telegram has made progress addressing its substantial debt obligations, repaying what Durov described as a "meaningful share" of its $2 billion in bonds this fall. The company had previously discussed the possibility of going public.Despite its financial success, Telegram continues to face regulatory challenges worldwide. Several countries, including Spain , Germany, and the UK, have considered bans or sanctions over the platform's minimal content moderation and alleged spread of misinformation. The service remains banned in China, Thailand , and Iran.The company has responded to some concerns by expanding its content moderation team to over 750 contractors. Durov maintains that the platform can achieve financial sustainability while "staying independent and respecting users' rights."
Article Summary: Telegram announces its first-ever profit in 2024. The company's revenue exceeded $1 billion this year, nearly triple its 2023 figure of $342 million. CEO Pavel Durov is currently unable to leave France following his August arrest over allegations of enabling criminal activity on the platform.

Article Title: Trading in Bharat Global Developers shares halted: What Zerodha CEO Nithin Kamath warned on 'Baap of Chart' and Trafiksol ITS Technologies
Article Text:
Zerodha CEO Nithin Kamath's 'warning' to investors

Scam stories: 'Baap of Chart' and Trafiksol ITS Technologies

The Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) has halted trading in Bharat Global Developers ' shares following concerns over an unusual price surge. The suspension comes in response to a complaint filed on December 16, accompanied by social media posts questioning the company’s financial transparency. The complaint pointed to an extraordinary rise in the company’s share price, which skyrocketed 105 times between November 2023 and November 2024.The price jumped from Rs 51.43 per share on December 26, 2023, to Rs 1,236.45 per share by December 23, 2024, a massive increase of 2,304%. The suspension once again highlights dangers of investing in stocks without strong fundamentals. This comes close on heels of SEBI imposing a fine of Rs 19 lakh on Sai Proficient Research Investment Advisory and its proprietor for regulatory violations, including misleading investors with false promises of returns.As Zerodha CEO Nithin Kamath too recently warned investors about prevalent stock market scams, citing two recent SEBI orders involving Trafiksol ITS Technologies IPO and "Baap of Chart." In a long post on X, formerly Twitter, and a blog post. In the blog, Kamath emphasized that seeking quick profits is a recipe for losing money.Kamath highlighted two distinct scams: One involving an SME IPO that raised Rs 44 crore to purchase software from a shell company with fabricated financials and a bogus client list, and another involving a financial influencer ("finfluencer") who amassed Rs 17 crore by selling courses and seminars. He reiterated the adage, "if something is too good to be true, it almost always is."Zerodha's blog post elaborated on these cases. The first involved an IPO where funds were supposedly earmarked for software acquisition from a vendor that turned out to be a shell company incapable of delivering the promised software. Despite this, the IPO was oversubscribed 345 times. The post outlined three key takeaways from SEBI's order: the vendor's lack of operational capability, fabricated financials and a fake client list, and a suspicious vendor selection process. SEBI had previously halted the Trafiksol ITS Technologies SME IPO pending investigation and subsequently ordered the company to refund investors.The second case involved "Baap of Chart," a finfluencer who promised high returns and ran an unauthorized investment advisory service, collecting significant sums from investors. SEBI's investigation revealed that he was not providing free advice but rather operating an unregistered advisory service. SEBI subsequently barred Nasiruddin Ansari and his associates from the securities market and ordered them to refund investors.Kamath has consistently addressed such fraudulent activities. He recently warned about the potential dangers of AI-driven scams, referencing a case where a Bengaluru techie lost ₹91 lakh in an online stock market scam. This underscores the increasing sophistication of scams and the need for investor vigilance.

Article Title: Apple App Store exposes children to harmful content despite safety claims, report finds
Article Text: Over 200 apps rated safe for children as young as four contain inappropriate content including stranger chat features, weight loss trackers, and violent games, according to a new report from child safety organizations released Monday. The 24-hour study by Heat Initiative and ParentsTogether Action reviewed 800 apps and found that problematic apps garnered more than 550 million combined downloads.The investigation uncovered widespread issues across apps rated 4+, 9+, or 12+ in categories like chat, beauty, diet, internet access, and gaming. Among the concerning discoveries were 25 chat apps enabling stranger communication with minors, apps promoting extreme dieting behaviors, and gaming apps soliciting inappropriate photos. Many apps also offered ways to bypass school and home internet filters, even while carrying ratings suitable for young children. Apple takes no legal responsibility for the veracity of age ratings," the report stated, despite the company's claims that the App Store is a "trusted place" for users. The study found nearly all weight loss and unfiltered internet access apps were approved for children aged four and above. The researchers called for several reforms, including implementation of independent third-party reviews, greater transparency in the app rating process, stronger enforcement of age ratings, and enhanced parental controls.While Apple conducts both automated and manual checks on apps and provides features like Screen Time for child protection, the company acknowledges that " App Store security measures alone can never be perfect." With nearly 2 million apps on the platform, comprehensive screening remains challenging. The report's authors emphasized that the most effective protection requires both improved app screening and engaged parenting, recommending that parents actively monitor their children's app usage and verify app safety through personal testing.The findings come amid broader scrutiny of the App Store, including a recent $1.95 billion EU fine over anti-competitive practices in March 2024. Apple has not yet commented on the report's findings.
Article Summary: Over 200 apps rated safe for children as young as four contain inappropriate content, a new report says. The investigation uncovered widespread issues across apps rated 4+, 9+ or 12+ in categories like chat, beauty, diet, internet access, and gaming. The researchers called for several reforms, including implementation of independent third-party reviews.

Article Text:
What NPCI advisory says

What is digital arrest scam



How to identify a digital arrest scam

Unexpected Contact from ‘Officials’: Be cautious if someone claims to be from government agencies like the police, CBI, income tax officers, or customs agents, contacts you. Be cautious especially if they claim urgent legal action is being initiated or warranted. They might allege that you or one of your family members is involved in a serious crime like money laundering, tax evasion, or drug trafficking.

Fear-based language and urgency: Scammers may request video calls, disguising themselves in police uniforms, using government logos, or creating official-sounding background noise to appear legitimate. They often threaten arrest or immediate legal action, demanding a quick response and using legal terms to sound convincing. In some cases, they create a police station-like set up to further convince victims of their credibility.

Request for sensitive information or payment: Scammers may ask for personal information or demand large sums of money, promising that this will clear up your involvement in the alleged crime. They may also coerce you to transfer money to their account until the investigation is complete. Terms like “clearing your name”, “assisting with the investigation”, or “refundable security deposit/escrow account” might be used by them to persuade you into transferring money to specified bank accounts or UPI IDs.

Tips to stay safe

Pause and Verify: If you receive unexpected calls or messages about legal issues, take a moment to verify. Stay calm, as scammers rely on fear and urgency. Real government and law enforcement agencies will never ask for money or investigate cases through phone or video calls. Always confirm the caller’s identity and consult trusted sources before taking any action.

Use Support Channels: Report suspicious numbers to the national cybercrime helpline by dialing 1930 or the Department of Telecommunication (https://sancharsaathi.gov.in/sfc/).

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‘party’ booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

Article Title: US government starts another investigation targeting these Chinese technology companies
Article Text: The Biden administration opened a trade investigation into China's production of older-style semiconductors , setting the stage for potential tariffs or other trade restrictions when President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.The probe, conducted under Section 301 of the Trade Act, targets " legacy chips " that power everyday devices from cars and household appliances to telecommunications equipment and military systems. U.S. officials warn that China's aggressive expansion in semiconductor production, backed by government subsidies, threatens to dominate global supply chains."China's policies are enabling its companies to rapidly expand and offer artificially lower-priced chips that threaten to significantly harm their market-oriented competition," said U.S. Trade Representative Katherine Tai . Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo revealed that two-thirds of U.S. products contain Chinese-made chips, with half of companies unaware of their chips' origin.The investigation will examine China's practices in producing silicon carbide substrates and other semiconductor components, with officials expressing concern that Chinese suppliers often price chips 30-50% below U.S. competitors. The Commerce Department projects China could control more than 40% of global capacity in foundational chips by 2032.China's Commerce Ministry strongly opposed the investigation, calling it "protectionist" and warning it would "take all necessary measures" to defend its interests. The ministry argued that U.S. companies dominate the global chip market and receive substantial government subsidies.The probe, which includes public hearings scheduled for March, will be handed to the incoming Trump administration for completion. The investigation could provide Trump a ready pathway to implement his proposed 60% tariffs on Chinese imports, though some industry groups urged caution about potential supply chain disruptions.
Article Summary: The Biden administration opened a trade investigation into China's production of older-style semiconductors. U.S. officials warn that China's aggressive expansion in semiconductor production, backed by government subsidies, threatens to dominate global supply chains. The investigation could provide Trump a ready pathway to implement his proposed 60% tariffs on Chinese imports.

Article Title: Netflix sues Broadcom-owned VMware over virtual machine patents
Article Text:
Netflix

What the Netflix lawsuit says

Netflix has filed a lawsuit against Broadcom in a California federal court, accusing the chipmaker's subsidiary, VMware, of infringing on its patents related to virtual machine technology, a report has said.According to a report by news agency Reuters, the lawsuit alleges that VMware's cloud software violates five Netflix patents covering various aspects of operating virtual machines, specifically focusing on the vSphere virtualization platform used for deploying and managing these virtual machines.Netflix's lawsuit claims that VMware's technology infringes on its patents related to virtual machine communications. Virtual machines are a key component of cloud computing, allowing multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.“Broadcom and VMware, jointly and severally, have infringed, and continue to infringe, at least Claim 1 of the ’424 Patent, either literally or under the doctrine of equivalents, by making, using, selling, and/or offering for sale within the United States and/or importing into the United States products that are covered by at least Claim 1 of the ’424 Patent. These products include, but are not limited to VMware vSphere Foundation, VMware Cloud Foundation, VMware Cloud on AWS, Azure VMware Solution, Google Cloud VMware Engine, Oracle Cloud VMware Solution, IBM Cloud for VMware Solutions, Alibaba Cloud VMware Service, as well as any other vSphere-based products and/or services (collectively, the “’424 Accused Products”),” Netlix said in the lawsuit.Netflix is seeking unspecified monetary damages in its new lawsuit against VMware, which was acquired by Broadcom for $69 billion last year.This new legal battle adds another layer to the existing patent dispute between Netflix and Broadcom that began in 2018. In the earlier case, Broadcom accused Netflix of infringing on its patents related to video streaming technology. That case is scheduled to go to trial in June 2025.
Article Summary: Netflix has filed a lawsuit against Broadcom's subsidiary,VMware. The lawsuit alleges thatVMware's cloud software violates five Netflix patents. The patents cover various aspects of operating virtual machines. Netflix is seeking unspecified monetary damages in its new lawsuit.

Article Title: Christmas 2024: How and when Google started tracking Santa Claus' journey from North Pole
Article Text:
How this Google tradition started



Google Santa tracker: How to use and top features



Google Santa Tracker , is a popular Christmas feature that allows users to track Santa Claus in real time as he delivers presents worldwide. This feature offers a digital way to follow Santa’s journey on Christmas Eve . Each December 24, Google transforms Santa's Village into an interactive tracking experience, delighting children and adults alike. The platform provides updates on Santa's route, showing his progress as he and his reindeer travel across the globe spreading Christmas cheer. Here’s how the tradition started:This festive tradition that began in 2004 builds on NORAD's long-standing Santa tracking program but has evolved with Google’s modern technology, incorporating playful features and educational games to engage users throughout the holiday season.Meanwhile, NORAD’s tradition of tracking Santa Claus on Christmas Eve began in 1955 when a misprint in a department store advertisement prompted a child to call a Colorado military command centre, hoping to speak with Santa Claus.Air Force Colonel Harry Shoup, who answered the call, pretended to be Santa and reassured the child. As more calls came in, Shoup assigned an officer to manage the enquiries, which started the festive custom that NORAD carried on after its establishment in 1958.For decades, NORAD has paused its regular airspace monitoring duties each holiday season to answer children’s questions about Santa’s journey and his remarkable gift-delivery mission. Each year, over 100,000 kids call in to track Santa’s location, while millions more follow his progress online in nine languages as he travels across the globe spreading holiday cheer.Santa's journey can be tracked using Google’s tool on iPhone, iPad or Mac by accessing the official Santa Tracking website through a web browser. The site includes a live map displaying Santa's current location, his next stop, a live video feed of his travels, and estimated arrival times for specific locations.The website also showcases photos of places Santa has already visited, a live tally of gifts delivered, and his current distance from the user's location. Additionally, it offers a variety of interactive activities, including games, creative projects, and videos, making the experience engaging and entertaining.
Article Summary: Google Santa Tracker is a popular Christmas feature that allows users to track Santa Claus in real time as he delivers presents worldwide. Article Title: Meta’s Chief AI Scientist Yann LeCun on why AI’s need to have emotions is not a requirement, but necessity
Article Text:
Representative image

AI systems will have emotions because…

Yann LeCun , Meta ’s Chief AI Scientist, has made a bold, or rather provocative, prediction: future AI systems will possess emotions. In a recent interview, LeCun explained that emotions are an “inseparable component” of the design of advanced AI systems.“So the blueprint of AI systems that we’re envisioning, that we’re going to build over the next few years — those AI systems will have emotions. It’s a basically inseparable component of the design of those systems,” he said while responding to a question at an interview.He argues that emotions are a natural consequence of AI agents being driven by objectives and goals.“Why would they have emotions? Because they will be driven by objectives,” LeCun explained. “You give them a goal that they have to accomplish, a task, and their purpose is to accomplish this task, subject to guardrails that are hardwired into their design,” he added.“And for them to do this, they need a number of components. The first component they need is a way to determine whether this goal that we give them was accomplished or not. And what they also need is what we call a world model. What is a world model is something that we all have — a prefrontal cortex that allows us to imagine what the consequences of our actions. And it’s what allows us to plan a sequence of actions to accomplish a particular goal. Now if you have this ability to predict ahead of time what a sequence of action is going to produce, then you can predict whether a goal is going to be satisfied or not. And you can predict if the outcome is going to be good or bad,” LeCun added.LeCun believes that this ability to predict and react to potential outcomes will give rise to emotions in AI.“If you predict it’s going to be bad, you feel fear. If you predict it’s going to be good, it’s more like elation, right? So, (you’ll need) the ability to predict, and then to act so as to accomplish those predictions (which) produces the equivalent of emotions. So AI systems that are smart enough, that are capable of reasoning and planning, will have emotions,” he explained.
Article Summary: Yann LeCun, Meta’s Chief AI Scientist, has made a bold, or rather provocative, prediction: future AI systems will possess emotions. He argues that emotions are a natural consequence of AI agents being driven by objectives and goals.

Article Title: SAP, Intel and 6 other companies who fired their top executives in the year 2024
Article Text:

Here’s a list of tech companies who were sacked, fired or laid off their top executives this year:Earlier this month, Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger was ousted by the company's board of directors Driven by mounting concerns over Intel's struggle to regain market share and compete effectively with rivals like Nvidia, the company took this decision According to a Bloomberg report, the board's confidence in Gelsinger's leadership eroded after a meeting last week where the company’s performance and future strategies were scrutinised. The departure of the World of Warcraft and Overwatch 2 developer added to the company's ongoing troubles. The studio’s Chief Design Officer Allen Adham also departed from Blizzard. Microsoft also shared plans to appoint a new Blizzard president within a week.In July, another gaming studio, Bungie announced the layoff of 220 employees accounting for nearly 17% of its workforce, amid rising development costs, industry shifts, and challenging economic conditions. This decision impacted all levels of the company, including many executive and senior leadership positions. Apart from this, Bungie also announced major changes to its cost structure, redirecting its development focus exclusively to titles Destiny and Marathon.In April, Elon Musk-led car maker Tesla announced layoffs. This followed a round of layoffs that reportedly impacted 14,000 employees.Last month, security technology company, Evolv Technologies, fired its CEO, Peter George, amid an ongoing investigation into its sales practices. The company's board of directors made the decision after months of deliberation. Michael Ellenbogen, the current chief innovation officer, was appointed as the interim CEO and president.Global technology company Comtech fired its CEO Ken Peterman for undisclosed reasons related to conduct in March. The company's board of directors appointed John Ratigan, the chief corporate development officer, as interim CEO while initiating a search for a permanent CEO.In July, US-based IT company Intuit laid off about 1,800 employees, affecting 10% of its workforce which also included top executives. With these job cuts, the company was trying to streamline operations and improve decision-making. While some layoffs were due to performance issues, others were part of a broader restructuring plan to consolidate teams and shut down certain offices.

Article Title: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work in Emerging Markets
Article Text:
More than Just Automation

Should we take the AI Leap of Faith?

What’s The

Future of Work

in the AI Era?

What does the future hold?

--- by Sajju Jain, Board Member, Entrepreneur, & Harvard Alum

Imagine, in the future, your colleague is not a person but an AI, tirelessly handling tasks with precision, completing work in seconds, and adapting to the latest industry trends before you even blink. That future isn’t a sci-fi movie plot, it’s happening right now!When considering AI’s impact on work, automation is often the first thing that comes to mind. Yet, for emerging markets , the applications are both broader and deeper. AI has evolved beyond simple task automation. It’s not just replacing human labour – it’s creating new possibilities for development and efficiency that were once unimaginable.For example, in healthcare, several AI startups are demonstrating how they can now automatically capture and consolidate a patient's tests and scans, their prescription information, and the clinician notes. This can provide a complete patient health snapshot to improve diagnosis, treatment, and give medical professionals more time with patients.Changes are also happening at the industry level where non-traditional players are competing with traditional healthcare providers. For example, Apple takes the vast amount of data it captures daily from users and creates a 'portable health record' for them. All this will help deliver better health outcomes, and the main beneficiaries will be emerging markets where it'll help lower costs and better utilize scarce resources like medical professionals.According to Accenture, AI can add up to $957 billion current gross value added to India's economy in 2035 by boosting productivity and creating significant new economic opportunities. Every other emerging market is also rushing to include AI at a national, industrial, and organizational level.For organizations, AI provides the potential to grow more effectively, reduce operational costs, and personalize customer experiences. According to the World Economic Forum’s recent report on the future of jobs, nearly 85% of Indian employers see AI as an opportunity to generate new jobs within the next 1-5 years and enhance the quality of existing roles. However, one of the most pressing challenges they face is the skill gap. AI demands a high level of language proficiency, data literacy, and analytical skills, which are not yet widespread among their workforces.To address this, organizations across emerging markets must invest in training and upskilling programs for their teams. Governments can support these initiatives by offering both financial and non-financial support.As AI becomes more integrated into our day-to-day lives, ethical considerations and data privacy concerns will become increasingly important. The NITI Aayog’s National Strategy for AI emphasizes the need for fairness, accountability, and transparency, especially when handling customer data.This means organizations, big or small, will need to establish clear data governance policies to comply with regulations and ensure that AI applications are ethical, fair, and non-discriminatory. Creating ethical AI isn't just about avoiding risk; it strengthens relationships with all stakeholders who know that their data is in safe hands.So, by embracing AI thoughtfully and responsibly, organizations can unlock unprecedented growth, streamline operations, and foster trust with stakeholders. Embracing AI and taking the leap of faith is not just worth taking, but essential for every organization's sustained success.The rise of AI is not just reshaping how we work but redefining what work means altogether. The future of work in India and other emerging markets will require a delicate balance between leveraging AI's capabilities and nurturing the uniquely human traits that set us apart. This transition isn't just about technology - it's about preparing people and organizations to thrive in a new era.All sectors of emerging economies are seeing growing demand for roles such as data analysts, AI trainers, cybersecurity experts, ethical AI consultants, and robotic process automation specialists. Interestingly, even roles in traditional fields like marketing, finance, and operations are also evolving to include more AI focused tasks, creating hybrid job profiles that combine core expertise with AI proficiency. For those in non-technical roles, learning how to work with AI tools for all types of roles will become a valuable skill.However, as these AI tools become ubiquitous and take on more data-heavy and process-driven tasks, stakeholders will place a premium on human interactions for competitive differentiation. Higher-level skills like emotional intelligence, creativity, and collaboration will play a critical role in AI-enabled workplaces. They'll help manage complex team dynamics, better support clients, and solve problems more effectively. So, having a mindset inclined towards continuous learning and adaptability will be critical for job security in this new landscape.The AI revolution is as unstoppable as the internet revolution was. It’s best that we embrace and guide it, instead of opposing it. The future of work for everyone in emerging markets will require creating a collaborative roadmap for responsible AI adoption – one that aligns technology with long-term goals and includes all impacted stakeholders, especially humans. Leaders across all types of organizations, both public and private, will need to work with their stakeholders to foster a culture that values continuous learning, encourages innovation, and helps their teams see AI as a tool to enhance, rather than replace, their work.
Article Summary: The rise of AI is not just reshaping how we work but redefining what work means altogether. The future of work in India and other emerging markets will require a delicate balance between leveraging AI's capabilities and nurturing the uniquely human traits that set us apart. Embracing AI and taking the leap of faith is essential for every organization's sustained success.

Article Title: Donald Trump's AI head Sriram Krishnan bats to remove country caps for Green Cards; here's why it is good news for Indians
Article Text:
How removal of country caps may be good news for Indians



Elon Musk agrees with Perplexity AI CEO

US President-elect Donald Trump recently appointed Chennai-born Indian-American entrepreneur and venture capitalist Sriram Krishnan as Senior Policy Advisor for AI at the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. Krishnan, known for his close association with tech billionaire Elon Musk , recently shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) saying “Anything to remove country caps for green cards / unlock skilled immigration would be huge.”When a user asked if removing country caps may backfire, Krishnan explained the logic stating “we need the best, regardless of where they happen to be born (another bizarre quirk - the country cap is where you were born, not even citizenship)”.David Sacks, appointed by Trump as “White House A.I. & Crypto Czar,” further clarified Krishnan’s proposed removal of country caps. Taking to X, he shared a post:“Point of clarification: Sriram didn’t say he wants to remove all caps on green cards. He said he wants to remove *country* caps on green cards. Right now, every country in the world gets allocated the same number of green cards, no matter how many qualified applicants it has.”Adding further, he said “So applicants from India have an 11 year wait whereas applicants from many other countries have no wait at all.”“Sriram still supports skills-based criteria for receiving a green card, not making the program unlimited. In fact, he wants to make the program entirely merit-based. Supporting a limited number of highly skilled immigrants is still a prevalent view on the right. Sriram is definitely not a “career leftist”!,” he stated.Highlighting to focus on skilled individuals over equal country representation, Perplexity AI CEO Arvind Srinivas commented on Sacks post, “Exactly. DOGE for immigration doesn’t mean more immigration or remove caps. Rather, it means let the best people in based on skill rather than trying to make sure every country is equally important.”Notably, Elon Musk responded to Srinivas’s post with a 💯, showing his full agreement.
Article Summary: US President-elect Donald Trump recently appointed Chennai-born Indian-American entrepreneur and venture capitalist Sriram Krishnan as Senior Policy Advisor for AI at the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. Krishnan, known for his close association with tech billionaire Elon Musk, recently shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) saying “Anything to remove country caps for green cards / unlock skilled immigration would be huge”

Article Title: Government warns mobile users of RBI credit card call scam
Article Text:
What is the fake voicemail

Tips to stay safe from fake voice calls

Be suspicious of unexpected calls:



If you receive a call from an unknown number or an unexpected caller, be cautious.

Legitimate organisations rarely make unsolicited calls for sensitive information.



Verify caller identity:



If the caller claims to be from a bank, government agency, or company you do business with, independently verify their identity.

Use official contact information (phone numbers, email addresses) found on their website to reach out directly.



Never share personal information:



Do not share your Social Security number, bank account details, credit card information, passwords, or any other sensitive information with unknown callers.



Don't fall for urgency tactics:



Scammers often create a sense of urgency to pressure you into making quick decisions.

Take your time, and don't let them rush you.



Hang up and report:



If you suspect a call is fraudulent, hang up immediately.

Report the call to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) at ReportFraud.ftc.gov.

You can also report it to your phone carrier.



Utilise call-blocking features:



Many phones and phone carriers offer call-blocking features.

Utilize these features to block suspected spam numbers.



A fraudulent call is making the rounds, falsely claiming to be from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The voicemail warns that your bank account will be blocked due to alleged fraudulent activity involving your credit card. However, PIB Fact Check has verified that these messages are completely fake and should be ignored.PIB Fact Check in its post on X (formerly known as Twitter) has confirmed that it is a fake voicemail and has asked users to stay aware. “Have you received a voicemail, allegedly from the Reserve Bank of India, claiming that your bank account will be blocked as your credit card has been involved in fraudulent activity #PIBFactCheck Beware! This is a scam.,” reads the post shared on X.All bank accounts in your name will be blocked in the next two hours for more information please press 9. Namastem yeah Bharti Reserve Bank — Your credit card has been involved in fraudulent activity.” After this the scammer will connect with the user and scam you.
Article Summary: A fraudulent call is making the rounds, falsely claiming to be from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) The voicemail warns that your bank account will be blocked due to alleged fraudulent activity involving your credit card. PIB Fact Check has verified that these messages are completely fake and should be ignored.

Article Title: Intel shareholders want fired CEO Pat Gelsinger to return three years of salary for these 5 ‘big mistakes’
Article Text:
Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger delivers a speech at the COMPUTEX forum in Taipei, Taiwan June 4, 2024. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

Intel shareholders have launched a derivative lawsuit against former CEO Pat Gelsinger and current CFO David Zinsner , demanding the return of $207 million in executive compensation following massive losses in the company's foundry business.The legal action, filed in federal court in San Jose, targets compensation paid to Gelsinger during his tenure from 2021 to 2023.The lawsuit, brought by LR Trust, alleges that Intel's leadership deliberately misled investors about the performance of Intel Foundry Services (IFS), which recorded a staggering $7 billion operating loss in 2023. According to court documents, the situation deteriorated further in 2024, with Q2 losses expanding to $2.83 billion, significantly worse than the $1.87 billion loss reported in Q2 2023.Shareholders claim that executives breached their fiduciary duties by maintaining an optimistic public stance about IFS despite its failure to attract major customers and mounting operational losses. The lawsuit specifically challenges Intel's 2024 Proxy Statement, arguing it failed to adequately disclose risks and misrepresented the foundry division's growth potential.The legal filing details five key allegations against Intel's leadership, including claims that IFS's reported growth metrics were misleading and that the division experienced declining product profit driven by lower internal revenue. These financial struggles ultimately led to company-wide layoffs and the suspension of Intel's dividend payments.This derivative lawsuit, which would return any awarded damages to Intel rather than individual shareholders, follows similar legal actions filed in June and August 2024. The mounting legal pressure comes in the wake of Gelsinger's resignation as CEO in December, marking a dramatic end to his vision of transforming Intel into a major player in the foundry business.The lawsuit also names various board members as defendants, accusing them of unjust enrichment and wasting corporate assets. Gelsinger had championed Intel's strategic pivot toward manufacturing chips for external customers when he announced the company's "internal foundry model" in October 2022, a move that shareholders now claim was mismanaged from the start.
Article Summary: Intel shareholders have launched a derivative lawsuit against former CEO Pat Gelsinger and current CFO David Zinsner. The lawsuit, brought by LR Trust, alleges that Intel's leadership deliberately misled investors about the performance of Intel Foundry Services (IFS) IFS recorded a staggering $7 billion operating loss in 2023.

Article Title: Epic Game Store’s 2024 holiday mystery games get less mysterious, and gamers are unhappy
Article Text: Epic Games Store 's 2024 holiday mystery game promotion has sparked controversy among users due to significant changes to its traditional format and what some consider disappointing game selections. The store has eliminated its practice of including hint-laden wrapping paper art, while also offering DLC instead of full games in some cases.The latest controversy peaked on December 23 when the platform offered Dark and Darker – Legendary Status DLC as its fifth mystery gift, requiring users to already own the base game. This marked a departure from previous years' offerings of complete games, leading to widespread disappointment among the community.A key point of contention is the removal of the promotional wrapping paper artwork that traditionally contained clues about upcoming games. While some users praise this change for maintaining genuine surprise, others lament the loss of the community guessing game that had become a holiday tradition.The promotion, running from December 19 to January 2, continues to offer daily free items instead of the store's usual weekly schedule. However, users have noted that this year's selections have been less notable compared to previous holiday giveaways.Adding to the changes, the usual pattern of advance leaks has been disrupted, with fewer accurate predictions circulating online. When leaks do occur, they now typically emerge just hours before releases, rather than days or weeks in advance as in previous years.The platform's holiday promotion will continue through early January, though the community remains divided over whether these changes represent an improvement or deterioration of the annual event.
Article Summary: Epic Games Store's 2024 holiday mystery game promotion has sparked controversy among users. The store has eliminated its practice of including hint-laden wrapping paper art, while also offering DLC instead of full games in some cases. Article Title: Two reasons why Microsoft may be exploring alternatives to OpenAI for 365 Copilot
Article Text:
Why Microsoft is making this change

Tension between Microsoft and OpenAI

Microsoft is reportedly looking beyond OpenAI to power its flagship AI product, Microsoft 365 Copilot . The tech giant is reportedly exploring the use of alternative language models. This marks a shift from the company's previous emphasis on its early access to OpenAI's models, which was a key selling point when 365 Copilot launched in 2023.Citing sources, news agency Reuters reported that Microsoft is also seeking to reduce 365 Copilot's reliance on OpenAI due to concerns about speed for enterprise users. The company is also aiming to reduce its reliance on OpenAI's technology and potentially lower costs.For this, Microsoft is reportedly training its own smaller models, like the recent Phi-4, and customising open-weight models to improve 365 Copilot's efficiency and performance.“We incorporate various models from OpenAI and Microsoft depending on the product and experience,” a Microsoft spokesperson told the agency, while confirming that OpenAI remains a partner for “frontier models.”The goal is also to potentially pass those savings to the end customer, and Microsoft's leaders, including CEO Satya Nadella, are said to be tracking the efforts closely.This move mirrors similar efforts in other Microsoft business units. GitHub, for example, recently added models from Anthropic and Google as alternatives to OpenAI's GPT-4o. Microsoft's consumer chatbot, Copilot, also now utilizes in-house models alongside OpenAI's technology.Several reports have suggested that the close partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI may be facing some challenges. Just a year after Microsoft played a key role in reinstating Sam Altman as OpenAI's CEO, their relationship appears to be showing signs of strain.While acknowledging the natural tensions in any partnership, Suleyman hinted at the diverging paths of the two companies."Every partnership has tension. It's healthy and natural. I mean, they're a completely different business to us. They operate independently and partnerships evolve over time... partnerships evolve and they have to adapt to what works at the time, so we'll see how that changes over the next few years," Suleyman said.
Article Summary: Microsoft is reportedly looking beyond OpenAI to power its flagship AI product. The tech giant is reportedly exploring the use of alternative language models. Article Title: Amazon and Starbucks workers are on strike. Why and how Donald Trump may have something to do with this
Article Text:
Amazon workers strike outside the gates of an Amazon Fulfillment Center. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

The 'likely Trump' factor behind the strikes

Amazon and Starbucks is joined by Elon Musk's Starlink

Strikes are underway at Amazon and Starbucks in several US cities as workers push for Union recognition and improved contracts. These actions follow a year of significant labour wins for Unions at companies like Boeing, and among dockworkers, video game performers, and Las Vegas casino workers. So what's behind the strikes at Amazon and Starbucks?Amazon reportedly refuses to formally acknowledge unionization efforts by its drivers and warehouse workers, despite some successful union votes and the Teamsters union claiming to represent them. Starbucks, while having agreed to negotiate, is facing criticism for slow progress.These strikes, particularly timed around the holiday season, aim to maximize pressure on the companies. The organizing drives at both companies gained momentum after the COVID-19 pandemic, which highlighted the importance of frontline workers and economic inequality. This period also saw successful unionization efforts at other retailers like Apple, Trader Joe's, and REI.A key factor driving the timing of these strikes is the upcoming change in presidential administration. With the potential for a less union-friendly National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) under a new administration, unions are attempting to leverage public pressure now. While some recent political appointments suggest a potentially more nuanced stance on labour relations, the immediate future of the NLRB remains a concern for unions.John Logan, director of labor and employment studies at San Francisco State University, told news agency AP that he thinks the Amazon and Starbucks workers are “desperate” to make progress before President-elect Donald Trump gets to appoint a Republican majority to the National Labor Relations Board, which is expected to be less friendly to unions during his administration.“The unions want to make these disputes public and bring political pressures on the companies," Logan said in a written statement. “If these disputes drag on until next year, and if they are fought largely through the labor board and the courts, the unions and workers will almost certainly lose. This might be their last, best chance to pressure the companies in public before Trump comes into office.”Amazon reportedly objected to the 2022 warehouse election results, reportedly claiming that the Amazon Labor Union and the federal labour board had tainted the vote. A regional NLRB director issued a complaint last year that accused Amazon of violating the law by refusing to bargain with the union.Amazon, in turn, is challenging the constitutionality of the NLRB in federal court along with Elon Musk 's SpaceX. In June, the US Supreme Court made it harder for the agency to win court orders in labour disputes, siding with Starbucks in a case brought by the company.
Article Summary: Strikes are underway at Amazon and Starbucks in several US cities as workers push for Union recognition and improved contracts. A key factor driving the timing of these strikes is the upcoming change in presidential administration. With the potential for a less union-friendly National Labor Relations Board under a new administration, unions are attempting to leverage public pressure now.
